content: The "Coeur d'Alene Basin Restoration Act of 1994" is cited as the short title. It amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to include the Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference. The Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference is established to develop a pollution prevention and restoration plan. The conference includes representatives from the EPA, Coeur d'Alene Indian tribe, and Idaho Department of Environmental Protection. The Management Conference appoints representatives from the EPA, Coeur d'Alene Indian tribe, and Idaho Department of Environmental Quality. Additionally, committees are formed including a management advisory committee, technical advisory committee, and citizens' advisory committee. Ex officio members are also included in the Management Conference. The Management Conference includes representatives from the EPA, Coeur d'Alene Indian tribe, and Idaho Department of Environmental Quality. Committees such as a management advisory committee, technical advisory committee, and citizens' advisory committee are formed. Ex officio members, including the Member of the United States House of Representatives within the Coeur d'Alene Basin congressional district, are also part of the Management Conference. A pollution prevention, control, and restoration plan must be published within one year of the enactment of this section. The Management Conference will publish a water pollution prevention, control, and restoration plan for the Coeur d'Alene Basin within one year of enactment. The plan will clarify responsibilities of Federal and State agencies and suggest a timetable for activities. The section clarifies duties of Federal and State agencies in water pollution prevention, funding methods for programs, and incorporates environmental management concepts. The curr_chunk discusses funding for programs, incorporating environmental management concepts, and developing a strategy for water pollution prevention in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. The curr_chunk focuses on including a strategy for water pollution prevention and control in the Coeur d'Alene Basin, promoting pollution prevention practices, and allowing for public review and comment on the draft Plan. The Management Conference will hold a public meeting in Idaho to hear comments on the draft Plan. The Administrator will approve the Plan if it meets requirements, and upon approval, it will be deemed an approved management program for conservation and management purposes. Upon approval of the Plan, it will be deemed an approved management program for conservation and management purposes. Grant assistance may be provided to water pollution control agencies. Grant assistance may be provided to State, interstate, and regional water pollution control agencies, as well as public or nonprofit agencies, institutions, and organizations for the development of the Plan, including research, surveys, studies, modeling, and technical work. The Administrator may establish terms and conditions for the administration of grants to assist in the development of the Plan, with a federal share not exceeding 70% of the costs and requiring a non-Federal share from non-Federal sources. The non-Federal share for grants may be provided through in-kind services. The term 'Coeur d'Alene Basin' refers to a specific watershed in northern Idaho. This section does not impact the jurisdiction or powers of any entity. The Coeur d'Alene Basin in northern Idaho includes the South Fork of the Coeur d'Alene River, the main stem of the Coeur d'Alene River, and Lake Coeur d'Alene. This section does not affect the jurisdiction or powers of any department or agency of the United States or any State, or any entity related to the Coeur d'Alene Basin created by treaty or memorandum. Appropriations are authorized to the Environmental Protection Agency for fiscal years 1995-1998. The United States is a signatory to treaties or memorandums related to the Coeur d'Alene Basin in Idaho. Appropriations are authorized to the Environmental Protection Agency for fiscal years 1995-1999. SEC. 3. FEDERAL PROGRAM COORDINATION. The Secretary of the Interior, in cooperation with the United States Geological Survey, will enhance data collection in the Coeur d'Alene Basin as part of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. This collaboration includes working with universities, research institutions, and state agencies in Idaho and Washington. The United States Geological Survey, in collaboration with universities, research institutions, and state agencies in Idaho and Washington, will develop an integrated geographic information system for the Coeur d'Alene Basin. They will convert partial recording sites to continuous monitoring stations and establish additional monitoring stations for data collection and monitoring purposes. The United States Geological Survey, in collaboration with other entities, will develop an integrated geographic information system for the Coeur d'Alene Basin. This includes converting partial recording sites to continuous monitoring stations and establishing additional stations for data collection and monitoring purposes. The Secretary of the Interior, through the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, will also be involved in a resource conservation program. The Department of the Interior, in cooperation with the Coeur d'Alene Fish and Wildlife Management Cooperative, will establish a fisheries resources restoration program in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. The Department of the Interior, in cooperation with the Coeur d'Alene Fish and Wildlife Management Cooperative, will establish a fisheries resources restoration program in the Coeur d'Alene Basin, including hatchery production and a wildlife species and habitat assessment survey. A survey will be conducted in the Coeur d'Alene Basin to assess Federal threatened and endangered species, migratory bird populations, and other species of special concern. The Director of the US Fish and Wildlife Service is authorized to carry out activities related to improving fishery resources and conducting investigations on migratory bird populations in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. The Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service is authorized to improve fishery resources, conduct investigations on the status of fishery resources, and update a survey of fishery resources in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. Authorization of appropriations is also provided. Authorization of appropriations is provided to the Department of the Interior for fiscal years 1995-1999 to improve fishery resources and habitats in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. SEC. 4. RESTORATION PLAN. The Secretary of the Interior, through the Bureau of Land Management, will cooperate with other natural resource trustees to develop a restoration plan for public lands in the Coeur d'Alene Basin to reduce human and environmental risks. The Secretary of the Interior will cooperate with other trustees to develop a restoration plan for public lands in the Coeur d'Alene Basin, including creating a computerized inventory of mining sites and contaminated areas for cleanup. The plan includes cleanup of mining contaminated sites, restoration of natural resources on public lands, and implementation of stream and river restoration plans in the Basin. The plan involves stream and river restoration, including rebuilding stream structure, placing wood debris and habitat structures, stabilizing banks, and planting riparian vegetation. Monitoring of restored areas will be conducted to assess effectiveness, and a land management plan will be developed in collaboration with various stakeholders. The plan includes developing a land management plan with stakeholders to reduce health and environmental risks, and maintaining a geographical information system for cultural and ecological resources in the Basin. The plan involves developing a land management plan to reduce health and environmental risks, maintaining a geographical information system for cultural and ecological resources, and collaborating with various wildlife agencies to develop habitat management plans for the Basin. Monitoring of wildlife management areas will also be provided. The plan includes developing habitat management plans for wildlife in the Basin, monitoring wildlife management areas for effectiveness, and collaborating with various agencies to create an integrated public recreation management plan. Fish and Game, Parks and Recreation, public health agencies, the Coeur d'Alene Indian tribe, and other recreation interests collaborate to develop an integrated public recreation management plan for the Basin. This includes implementing a lake and river information program to provide public use and health risk information. The Director of the United States BLM has powers to achieve the goals outlined. The Director of the United States Bureau of Land Management has the authority to carry out activities related to data collection, inventory of mining waste areas, data management of resource information, and acquiring contaminated lands for restoration and management to minimize health and environmental risks. The Director of the United States Bureau of Land Management is responsible for activities such as acquiring mining contaminated lands for restoration, designing and maintaining restoration projects, overseeing construction of repositories for mine waste, and developing long-term restoration and land management plans. The Bureau of Land Management is responsible for acquiring mining contaminated lands for restoration, overseeing construction of repositories for mine waste, developing long-term restoration and land management plans, and providing maintenance of restored public lands. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 1995-2002 to carry out these activities. The Environmental Protection Agency and the Department of the Interior are exempt from liability under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 for actions taken under this Act.
